reviews.text: generic dark fantasy storyline is pointless
worst-in-class textures and character models suck any visual appeal out of what could have been an interesting painted-canvas art style
Combat and level design are both competent but plain in single-player or co-op, with just enough good ideas sprinkled in to keep things from immediately growing stale… though it inevitably does
running from point A to point B, navigating linear corridors as you race to your objective
jumping... input lag, coupled with an unusually flat arc, makes gauging jumps more frustrating than it should be
the cycle grows tedious as you repeat it dozens of times
it’s always disappointing to see pay to win scenarios
story... exposition-heavy still images, zooming from one fibrous picture frame to another
hints of a distinctive art style are wasted on drab environments and jilted action
combat... devolves into extended bouts of pure button-mashing while you watch health bars slowly decrease
joining up with a group of Sentinels has no strategic value beyond making missions pass more quickly
everything is covered in textures that genuinely would’ve been unimpressive on the PS3
perpetual treadmill of increasing your power to take on greater challenges keeps the campaign afloat, but here it’s bare bones and rarely does it offer a twist to make progression compelling
Babylon’s Fall feels like the generic store brand of more famous games that came before

the ability to level up a favorite piece of equipment is held until late in the campaign, which is a smart decision that forces you to jump around between different weapon combinations as you earn more powerful loot instead of just finding one that works and sticking to it
the action of jumping... input lag makes gauging jumps frustratinging

the endgame... high-level variations on missions... become available as opportunities to earn the most powerful gear. Skirmishes may contain Infamous enemies that drop special loot, while Sieges emphasize combat or platforming. You also unlock new attack patterns and alternative abilities for your Gideon Coffin. Given how repetitive the campaign missions got before I reached the endgame, holding these more interesting additions until the end is a questionable choice
the worst-in-class textures and character models
the combat is competent, but not engaging and prone to degrading into repetitive button mashing
the world of Babylon’s Fall could have been constructed via Mad Libs
the Gideon Coffin’s weapon slots can dramatically alter damage output and survivability, but combat devolves into button mashing against tougher enemies
the endgame’s Skirmishes and Sieges are variations on missions, but they do little to change the actual experience of playing
the game’s perpetual treadmill of power progression is bare bones and rarely compelling
the game’s art style’s potential is wasted on drab environments
the game’s co-op lacks strategic value beyond speeding up missions
the game’s jumping mechanics have input lag and poor arc, making them frustratinging
the game’s endgame offers no meaningful twists to combat or progression
the game’s story is told through exposition-heavy still images with no emotional connection
the game’s art direction’s potential is overshadowed by poor textures and models
the game’s combat devolves into repetitive button mashing against tougher enemies
the game’s co-op lacks strategic roles like tanking or support, reducing it to just more bodies
the game’s endgame’s pay-to-win elements include performance-affecting rewards
